name: Hindu Mythology
tagline: The Eternal Dharma and Divine Cycles
description: Explore the vast cosmos of Hindu mythology, where gods take endless forms and the universe dances through eternal cycles of creation and destruction.
overview: Hindu mythology (Sanatan Dharma - the Eternal Way) encompasses one of the world's oldest and most complex religious traditions, with roots stretching back over 4,000 years to the Vedic period. This rich mythological tapestry features the Trimurti (Brahma the Creator, Vishnu the Preserver, Shiva the Destroyer), countless devas and devis manifesting divine principles, epic narratives of the Ramayana and Mahabharata, the concept of avatar (divine incarnation), the cosmic dance of creation and destruction, karma and reincarnation across countless lifetimes, and paths of yoga leading to moksha (liberation). Unlike Western mythologies with definitive beginnings and endings, Hindu mythology operates in vast cosmic cycles (yugas and kalpas) where the universe is eternally born, sustained, destroyed, and reborn. The tradition embraces paradox, with the ultimate reality (Brahman) being both personal and impersonal, manifest and unmanifest, one and many.

sections.title: The Trimurti: Creation, Preservation, Destruction
sections.body:
The three primary aspects of the divine cosmic function:

**Brahma (‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ) - The Creator:** Four-faced god who creates the universe at the beginning of each cosmic cycle. Rides Hamsa (swan), holds the Vedas, and is often depicted seated on a lotus emerging from Vishnu's navel. Despite his importance in cosmology, few temples worship Brahma directly.

**Vishnu (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å) - The Preserver:** Blue-skinned god who maintains cosmic order (dharma) and descends to Earth in various avatars when evil threatens to overwhelm good. Rides Garuda (eagle), holds conch, discus, mace, and lotus. His consort is Lakshmi (prosperity). Major avatars include Rama and Krishna.

**Shiva (‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ) - The Destroyer/Transformer:** The lord of yoga, asceticism, and cosmic dance (Nataraja). Third eye on forehead, crescent moon in matted hair, Ganga river flowing from his locks, serpent Vasuki around neck. Destroys the universe at the end of each cosmic cycle to enable renewal. His consort is Parvati (taking fierce form as Kali or Durga). Rides Nandi the bull.

These three represent the eternal cycle of creation-preservation-destruction that governs all existence. They are not separate beings but different aspects of Brahman (ultimate reality).

sections.title: The Dashavatara: Vishnu's Divine Incarnations
sections.body:
Vishnu descends to Earth in various forms (avatars) to restore dharma when evil threatens cosmic order. The ten primary avatars (Dashavatara) show cosmic evolution:

1. **Matsya (‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø) - The Fish:** Saved Manu and the Vedas from the great flood
2. **Kurma (‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ) - The Tortoise:** Supported Mount Mandara during the churning of the cosmic ocean
3. **Varaha (‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π) - The Boar:** Rescued Earth (Bhudevi) from the demon Hiranyaksha
4. **Narasimha (‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π) - The Man-Lion:** Destroyed the demon Hiranyakashipu who could not be killed by man or beast
5. **Vamana (‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®) - The Dwarf:** Took three steps to reclaim the three worlds from demon king Bali
6. **Parashurama (‡§™‡§∞‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ) - Rama with Axe:** Warrior who destroyed corrupt kshatriyas (warriors)
7. **Rama (‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ) - Prince of Ayodhya:** Hero of the Ramayana, exemplar of dharmic kingship
8. **Krishna (‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£) - The Divine Cowherd:** Teacher of Bhagavad Gita, central figure of Mahabharata
9. **Buddha (‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß) - The Enlightened One:** (In some traditions) Taught compassion and non-violence
10. **Kalki (‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø) - The Future Warrior:** Yet to come, will end the Kali Yuga riding a white horse

These avatars represent increasing complexity - from aquatic to amphibian to mammal to human to superhuman - mirroring evolutionary development.

sections.title: Yugas: The Cosmic Ages
sections.body:
Time in Hindu cosmology operates in vast cycles (yugas) characterized by declining dharma:

**Satya Yuga (Krita Yuga) - Age of Truth:** 1,728,000 years. Humans are virtuous, live long lives, possess divine knowledge. Dharma walks on four legs (complete).

**Treta Yuga - Age of Three:** 1,296,000 years. Righteousness declines by 1/4. Sacrifices and rituals begin. Dharma walks on three legs. (Age of Rama)

**Dvapara Yuga - Age of Two:** 864,000 years. Dharma reduced by half. Disease, desire, and discord increase. (Age of Krishna)

**Kali Yuga - Age of Discord:** 432,000 years (current age, began c. 3102 BCE). Only 1/4 dharma remains. Characterized by strife, ignorance, irreligion, vice. Kalki avatar will end this age.

A complete cycle (Maha Yuga) = 4,320,000 years. 1,000 Maha Yugas = 1 Kalpa (day of Brahma = 4.32 billion years). At night, Brahma sleeps and the universe dissolves, only to be recreated at dawn. Brahma lives 100 Brahma years, after which complete dissolution (Maha Pralaya) occurs before a new Brahma is born.

sections.title: Karma & Samsara: The Wheel of Rebirth
sections.body:
**Karma (‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ):** The law of cause and effect governing moral action. Every action, thought, and intention creates karma - either good (punya) or bad (papa). This karma determines future circumstances and rebirths.

**Samsara (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞):** The cycle of death and rebirth (reincarnation) driven by karma. All beings - from insects to gods - are trapped in samsara, experiencing countless lives across different realms until achieving liberation.

**Six Realms of Rebirth:**
- Deva-loka (gods) - heavenly pleasures but still impermanent
- Asura-loka (demigods) - power-hungry beings in constant conflict
- Manushya-loka (humans) - considered the best realm for spiritual progress
- Tiryak (animals) - driven by instinct
- Preta-loka (hungry ghosts) - beings tormented by insatiable desires
- Naraka (hells) - temporary realms of suffering for purification

**Moksha (‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑):** Liberation from samsara - the ultimate goal of human existence. Achieved through:
- Jnana Yoga (knowledge/wisdom)
- Bhakti Yoga (devotion)
- Karma Yoga (selfless action)
- Raja Yoga (meditation)

Moksha represents union with Brahman (ultimate reality), ending the cycle of rebirth and achieving eternal bliss (ananda).

sections.title: The Great Epics: Ramayana & Mahabharata
sections.body:
**Ramayana (‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£):** Composed by Valmiki (c. 500 BCE). The story of Rama, prince of Ayodhya and avatar of Vishnu, who with his wife Sita and brother Lakshmana defeats the demon king Ravana. Central themes: dharma (duty), devotion, ideal kingship, loyalty. Hanuman, the monkey god, exemplifies perfect devotion. The text explores the cost of maintaining dharma even when it causes personal suffering.

**Mahabharata (‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§):** The world's longest epic poem (100,000 verses), traditionally attributed to Vyasa. Chronicles the dynastic struggle between Pandavas and Kauravas, culminating in the devastating Kurukshetra War. Central to the epic is the **Bhagavad Gita** - dialogue between Arjuna and Krishna on the battlefield, addressing duty, devotion, knowledge, and the nature of reality. The Gita remains the most widely read Hindu scripture.

Themes include: the complexity of dharma, the consequences of desire and pride, the role of fate vs. free will, the importance of counsel, and the devastating nature of war even when fighting for righteousness.

sections.title: Shakti: The Divine Feminine
sections.body:
**Shakti (‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø):** The primordial cosmic energy - the dynamic creative force of the universe. All goddesses are manifestations of Shakti.

**Devi (‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä) - The Great Goddess:** Ultimate reality in Shaktism (goddess-centered tradition). Manifests in numerous forms:

**Benevolent Forms:**
- **Lakshmi (‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä):** Consort of Vishnu, goddess of wealth, prosperity, fortune
- **Saraswati (‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä):** Consort of Brahma, goddess of learning, music, arts, wisdom
- **Parvati (‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä):** Consort of Shiva, gentle mother goddess, daughter of mountains

**Fierce Forms:**
- **Durga (‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ):** Warrior goddess who rides a lion/tiger, slays demons, protects cosmic order. Has eight/ten arms wielding divine weapons
- **Kali (‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä):** Fearsome dark goddess of time, death, and transformation. Wears skull garland, drinks demon blood, dances on Shiva's corpse. Represents the destruction of ego and illusion.

**Tantric Goddesses:**
- The Ten Mahavidyas (wisdom goddesses) including Tara, Tripura Sundari, Bhuvaneshwari, Chinnamasta

Shakti-Shiva duality represents the dynamic dance of creation - Shiva (consciousness) is inert without Shakti (energy). Together they create, sustain, and dissolve the universe.

sections.title: Sacred Geography & Holy Sites
sections.body:
**Mount Meru (‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Å):** The cosmic mountain at the center of the universe, home of the gods. The North Star sits above it. Around it revolve sun, moon, and stars.

**Seven Holy Rivers:** Ganga (Ganges), Yamuna, Godavari, Saraswati, Narmada, Sindhu, Kaveri. The Ganga descended from heaven through Shiva's hair.

**Four Sacred Cities (Char Dham):** Badrinath (north), Puri (east), Rameshwaram (south), Dwarka (west)

**Seven Sacred Cities:** Ayodhya, Mathura, Haridwar, Varanasi (Kashi), Kanchipuram, Ujjain, Dwarka

**Kailash Parvat (‡§ï‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂):** Mountain abode of Shiva and Parvati in the Himalayas

**Vaikuntha (‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†):** Vishnu's celestial paradise

**Kashi/Varanasi:** Most sacred city, where dying grants instant moksha. Here the Ganga flows north toward its heavenly source.

**Kumbh Mela:** Massive pilgrimage occurring every 12 years where millions bathe in sacred rivers for purification.

sections.title: Primary Sacred Texts
items: Rigveda (c. 1500-1200 BCE) - Oldest Vedic hymns to gods
Yajurveda, Samaveda, Atharvaveda - The four Vedas (revealed knowledge)
Upanishads (c. 800-200 BCE) - Philosophical texts exploring Brahman and Atman
Bhagavad Gita (c. 200 BCE) - Krishna's teachings to Arjuna, part of Mahabharata
Mahabharata (c. 400 BCE-400 CE) - World's longest epic, Kurukshetra War
Ramayana (c. 500 BCE) - Epic of Rama, ideal dharmic king
Puranas (c. 300-1000 CE) - Mythological encyclopedias (18 major, 18 minor)
Brahma Purana, Vishnu Purana, Shiva Purana - Sectarian mythologies
Yoga Sutras of Patanjali - Classical yoga philosophy
Tantras - Esoteric texts of Shakti worship and ritual

parallels.connection: Direct historical connection - Buddhism emerged from Hindu context, shares many deities and concepts
Indo-European roots - sky father (Dyaus/Zeus), similar pantheon structures
Indo-European parallels - cosmic trees, world destruction/renewal cycles
Indo-Iranian heritage - shared Vedic-Avestan roots, similar fire worship
